content:
I am working with a pandas DataFrame that is time-indexed. Here's an example of the data I'm dealing with:

```python
df2 = pd.DataFrame({ 
    'day': pd.Series([date(2012, 1, 1), date(2012, 1, 3)]), 
    'b' : pd.Series([0.22, 0.3]) 
})
df2 = df2.set_index('day')
df2
               b
 day             
2012-01-01  0.22
2012-01-03  0.30
```

I want to extend this DataFrame to include one row for every day in January 2012. For any dates that do not have data, I would like the 'b' column to be set to NaN. The desired output would look like this:

```python
               b
 day             
2012-01-01  0.22
2012-01-02   NaN
2012-01-03  0.30
2012-01-04   NaN
...
2012-01-31   NaN
```
What's the best way to achieve this?

To extend your DataFrame to include one row for every day in January 2012 and fill in missing dates with NaN values in the 'b' column, you can use the `pd.date_range` function to generate a complete date range for January 2012, and then reindex your DataFrame to this date range. Here is how you can achieve this:

```python
import pandas as pd
from datetime import date

# Original DataFrame
df2 = pd.DataFrame({ 
    'day': pd.Series([date(2012, 1, 1), date(2012, 1, 3)]), 
    'b' : pd.Series([0.22, 0.3]) 
})
df2 = df2.set_index('day')

# Generate a complete date range for January 2012
full_date_range = pd.date_range(start='2012-01-01', end='2012-01-31')

# Reindex the DataFrame to include all dates in the date range
df2_full = df2.reindex(full_date_range)

# Print the result
print(df2_full)
```

This code will create a DataFrame with all dates in January 2012 as the index, filling in missing dates with NaN values in the 'b' column. The output will be:

```plaintext
              b
2012-01-01  0.22
2012-01-02   NaN
2012-01-03  0.30
2012-01-04   NaN
...
2012-01-31   NaN
```

This method ensures that your DataFrame includes every day of the specified month, with missing values filled with NaN.
